title-group.article-title: Processing and characterization of composites of poly(3-hydroxybutyrate-co-hydroxyvalerate) and lignin from sugar cane bagasse

contrib-group.aff: 1Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, Campinas, SP, Brazil.
2Institute of Chemistry, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, SP, Brazil.

author-notes.corresp: Ana Paula Lemes, Institute of Chemistry, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, P.O. Box 6154, 13083-970 Campinas, SP, Brazil; Institute of Science and Technology, Universidade Federal de São Paulo, 12231-280 São José dos Campos, SP, Brazil Email: aplemes@unifesp.br

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A biodegradable polymer composite containing lignin from sugarcane bagasse and poly(3-hydroxybutyrate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate) (PHBV) was produced and characterized in terms of its thermal, morphological, and mechanical properties. For comparison with the properties of the composites, the properties of the isolated composite components (lignin and PHBV) were also determined. The characterizations were carried out by Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and mechanical properties. In the micrograph images, no physical contact between filler and matrix was verified. The thermal decomposition profiles of composites depend on the lignin/PHBV proportions, and their residual mass increased as a function of lignin amount. Higher temperatures were necessary to promote PHBV crystallization in the presence of lignin. However, the crystalline degree of composites was not affected by the lignin. The results obtained in the mechanical tests showed that the lignin addition caused a decrease of mechanical properties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Advances in science and technology require a variety of new polymers with good performance and low cost. However, it is becoming more difficult to find the necessary properties from the limited number of available homopolymers. Thus, polymer composites, alloys and other composite materials have been studied for new materials.1,2

Environmentally degradable plastics are an attractive route to environmental waste management and can replace conventional polymers when recovery for recycling or incineration is difficult and not cost-effective. Research has focused on the addition of a natural or synthetic biodegradable polymer to a non-degradable commodity plastic or to another biodegradable polymer.3,4

Many natural polymers are candidates for the production of new plastic formulations for many applications, depending on their chemical, thermal, and mechanical properties.5,6 Poly(3-hydroxybutyrate) (PHB) and its copolymers, among them, poly(3-hydroxybutyrate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate (PHBV), a polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA) family member obtained from bacteria, is a good option for the future. Many efforts have also been made to utilize waste lignins7 as a raw material for the chemical industry and progress has been made on the development of new materials from lignocellulosic residues.

Efforts to improve the crystalline properties of PHB by combining it with other polymers have been reported.8,9 The crystallinity of PHBV is being examined by many researchers because, different from PHB, it is more flexible due to the presence of the hydroxyvalerate units (HV) in its structure, with an extra –CH2 group in the chain, responsible for a decrease in crystallinity.

PHBV and the other members of the polyhydroxyalkanoate family are biocompatible, biodegradable,10,11 and piezoelectric thermoplastics, with potential applications in the medical, agricultural, and marine fields. However, at the moment, a major drawback to commercialization of these products is their high price compared to conventional petrochemical-based plastic materials. As an intracellular product, their recovery contributes significantly to the overall economics, and developing a process that allows a simple, efficient and less polluted recovery of PHA from microorganisms is an attractive proposal.12

Many studies have been carried out in order to improve the mechanical properties of PHBV and to decrease the production costs, to make it available for industrial applications. Among these studies, one can cite the use of platicizing agents,13 composites including mixtures of natural polymers such as poly(ε-caprolactone) (PCL), poly(L-lactic acid) (PLA), amides and cellulose,14,15 and with synthetic polymers, such as poly(epichlorohydrine), polyvinylphenol, oxidized polyethylene, oxidized polypropylene,16,17 and natural biopolymers such as natural rubber, avaca, bamboo, purified cellulose, hemp, henequen, kenaf, wood fibers, rice straw, lignin esters, and bagasse.18–28

Another alternative in this direction is the inclusion of polymeric charges in the PHBV that is used in thermoplastics. This would contribute to a competitive price for the material and in general to an improvement in its thermal and mechanical properties.29,30

In many cases, lignins are used only as low-cost fillers, and the objective is to minimize the loss of ultimate mechanical properties. So, the aim of this work was the application of a low cost lignin from the soda pulping process by extraction of steam-exploded sugarcane bagasse with 1% NaOH, as filler for PHBV in order to obtain an economical composite that is an ecologically feasible biodegradable product and verify the effects of this lignin in the thermal and mechanical properties of PHBV matrix.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Lignin/PHBV composite samples were prepared using lignin from sugarcane bagasse, supplied by FAENQUIL-Lorena, SP, Brazil. Briefly: Lignin from the soda pulping process (SEBL) was obtained by extraction of steam-exploded sugarcane bagasse with 1% NaOH at 100°C.31 Lignin dissolved in the soda liquor was isolated by precipitation with HCl or H2SO4 at pH 2 in a 200 L reactor. The precipitated lignin was separated in a press filter and thoroughly washed with water until complete absence of sulfate or chloride.32
PHBV with 18% of 3-hydroxyvalerate (HV) units and Mw 420 kDa was kindly supplied by PHB Industrial.

sec.title: Preparation of composites
sec.p: Lignin/PHBV composites with 0:100, 20:80, 40:60, 50:50, 60:40, and 80:20 lignin/PHBV (w/w) ratios were prepared in a Haake Fisions Rheocord 90 batch mixer using 8 min at 175°C and 90 rpm.

With the aim of producing specimens for mechanical tests, the 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composite and pure PHBV were processed in a single screw extruder of diameter 19.1 mm, (L/D = 25 mm) from Haake. After, these samples were ground and injected into an ARBURG 221 injection molding machine with five heating zones, under the following conditions: injection volume of 13.5 cm3, injection time of 22 s, injection pressure of 1200 bar, injection velocity of 2.6 mm/s. The temperature profile of injection molding machine was: 145°C (feed zone), 160, 165 and 165°C (compression zones), and 160°C (metering zone).
A sample of pure and not extruded PHBV (in nature) was injected under the same conditions to obtain specimens for mechanical tests.
PHBV and lignin samples were dried overnight at 80°C before their processing.

sec.title: Characterization of composites
sec.p: Pure polymers and composites were analyzed by Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), using a Bomen Michelson MB Series instrument, with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and KBr windows. For the FTIR analysis, all samples were prepared under vacuum to eliminate the effect of adsorbed water interference and to protect the KBr window.

Differential scanning calorimetry was carried out in a DSC 2910 from TA instruments, under a nitrogen flow of 100 mL min-1 using the following procedure: (1) heating from room temperature to 200°C at 10°C min-1; (2) isothermal conditions for 2 min at 200°C; (3) cooling to –30°C at 10°C min−1; (4) isothermal conditions for 5 min at −30°C and (5) second heating to 200°C at 10°C min−1. The first heating followed by cooling was necessary to erase the thermal history of the samples.
The thermogravimetric analysis was done under a continuous argon flow of 100 mL min−1 with heating from room temperature to 970°C at a heating rate of 10°C min−1.

The surface morphology of each component (lignin, PHBV) and each lignin /PHBV composite were observed by SEM, with secondary electrons, equipped with a tungsten filament, in a Jeol T-300 operating at 15 keV. The same was done to observe the cross section surface after cryogenic fracture of the samples. The samples were fixed onto metallic stubs with carbon tape to prevent electronic charging on insulating surfaces. They were coated with a thin layer of gold for 120 s with a Bal-Tec sputtering instrument.

Tensile and flexural properties were measured for 50:50 lignin/PHBV according ASTM D-638 and ASTM D-790, respectively, using an EMIC DL 2000 testing machine with load cell of 5000 N and crosshead speed of 5.0 mm min−1. For mechanical tests, the specimens were kept at 25°C and 50% of humidity for 48 h to reach the equilibrium state before their mechanical tests.

The shape and dimensions of the specimens for tensile and flexural tests were carried out following the ASTM D-638 and ASTM D-790 standards procedures, respectively. For flexural tests the specimens were rectangular with 125 mm × 12 mm × 3 mm (length × width × thickness). The shape and dimension values of specimens for tensile test are showed in detail in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Shape and dimensions of tensile test specimens.

sec.title: FT-infrared spectra
sec.p:
The infrared spectra show chemical groups present in lignin,33 PHBV and 50:50 lignin/PHBV composite can be verified in the infrared spectra shown in the Figure 2. The band at 3437 cm−1 corresponds to OH groups present in the chemical structure of lignin and PHBV. The OCH3 groups, O–H (phenolic) and C–C (aromatic) are characteristic of lignin and correspond to stretching vibration at 2849 cm−1, 1597 cm−1, and 1219 cm−1, respectively. The band at 2920 cm−1 is related to the C–H stretching vibration of methyl groups of both lignin and PHBV. The bands at 1219 cm−1 correspond to C–O and at 1718 cm−1 correspond to C = O stretchings. Figure 2.
Infrared spectrum: (a) Lignin, (b) PHBV, and (c) 50:50 lignin/PHBV.
No significant change was observed in the IR spectra of 50:50 lignin/PHBV composite, seemingly, this spectrum consist of overlapping bands of lignin and PHBV.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC)
sec.p:
The Tg (glass transition temperature), Tc (crystallization temperature- exothermic peak), Tm (melting temperature- endothermic peak) and the ΔHm (variation of melting enthalpy) of lignin, PHBV and all composites were supplied by DSC curves shown in Figure 3. As PHBV is the only crystalline component in the composite, their comparison must be done through the calculated ΔHm, which considers the PHBV content in the sample. Thus, the experimental ΔHm of each composite was corrected to 100% of PHBV (Equation (1)) to obtain the calculated ΔHm. In Equation (1), XPHBV corresponds to fraction of PHBV in each composite (from 0.2 to 0.8). (1) Figure 3.
DSC curves of (a) PHBV (pure); lignin/PHBV composites: (b) 20:80, (c) 40:60, (d) 50:50, (e) 60:40, (f) 80:20, and (g) lignin.

The Tg, Tc, Tm, experimental ΔHm and calculated ΔHm for each composite are summarized in Table 1. The lignin/PHBV composites showed the same values or small shifts of Tg, Tc, and Tm, it indicates that the thermal behavior did not undergo high alterations in function of composite composition, with the exception of the high Tc of 60:40 and 80:20 lignin/PHBV composites. The increase of Tc in these composites occurred probably because the process of PHBV crystallization becomes more difficult in the presence of high amounts of lignin. However, the similar values of calculated ΔHm for all composites indicate that lignin does not affect the crystalline degree of PHBV. Table 1.
Tg, Tc, and Tm values of composites, PHBV (pure) and lignin (pure), (ND – Not Detected)
Lignin/PHBV Tg (°C) Tc (°C) Tm (°C) ΔHm (J g−1) experimental ΔHm (J g−1) calculated
0:100 a −2 36 169 64 –
0:100 b −2 39 169 58 –
20:80 −3 36 167 49 61
40:60 −2 38 166 38 63
50:50 −2 38 165 31 62
60:40 0 43 166 25 63
80:20 1 51 163 12 62
100:0 c ND ND ND ND –
a
Pure PHVB. b
Processed PHBV in Haake mixer. c
Pure lignin.

Although the processed PHBV showed a small decrease of ΔHm, the processing in the Haake mixer did not cause changes in the PHBV thermal behavior, since the values shown in Table 1 were the same for unprocessed PHBV and processed PHBV (0:100).

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analyses
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the TGA curves of lignin/PHBV composites and their isolated components. The thermal decomposition of pure PHBV occurs in a unique step, between 280 and 300°C and do not produce char residue as observed in its thermogravimetric curve in Figure 4(a). Thermal degradation of PHBV occurs almost exclusively via a random chain scission by cis-elimination mechanism, involving a six-members ring transition state.34,35 Figure 4.
TGA curves: (a) PHBV; lignin/PHBV composites: (b) 20:80, (c) 40:60, (d) 50:50, (e) 60:40, (f) 80:20, and (g) lignin.

On the other hand, the TGA curve of lignin (Figure 4(g)) shows several decomposition steps. The thermal decomposition of lignin takes place over a wide temperature range and gives rise to high amounts of volatile products with low molar masses due to its complex and heterogeneous chemical structure, as well as significant amounts of solid residue (char).36,37 The high char yield is related to the presence of inorganic components.38

Water, formaldehyde, methane, and methanol are the main products released in lignin thermal decomposition. While the water and formaldehyde are produced primarily by the cleavage of aliphatic hydroxyl groups, methane and methanol are produced by the scission of the methoxyl groups.36,39 Moreover, water evolution occurs over in a wide temperature range, indicating multiple origins of water, as also occurs for CO and CO2 evolutions.40

The thermal decomposition of all composites occurs first in a step similar to pure PHBV, between 280 and 300°C, which is attributed to decomposition of the PHBV content in the composites. Above 300°C, the shape of weight loss curve shows several decomposition steps similar to pure lignin. The profile change of composites TGA curves occurs according to lignin/PHBV ratio. Thus, for 50:50 lignin/PHBV composite the profile change happens at 50%, while for 20:80 lignin/PHBV it happens at 20%. However, the main effect caused by lignin addition can be observed in the residual mass of TGA curves.

While no residue was observed in the PHBV decomposition, in the lignin/PHBV composites the increase of residual mass is noted as functions of lignin percentage. This occurs because the pyrolysis of lignin (decomposition by heating in the partial or total absence of oxygen) results in production of char residue, thus, the higher the lignin amount in the composites, the higher is the amount of char residue.

It was expected that the char residue of all composites was lower than pure lignin, nevertheless, the 50:50 and 80:20 composites were the only ones that generated char residue higher than pure lignin.

The same was not observed in the TGA curves of PHBV/Lignosulfonate samples studied by Lemes et al.41 In their work, all PHBV/Lignosulfonate samples (90:10; 80:20; 70:30; 60:40 w/w) showed lower amount of char residue than pure lignosulfonate, as expected. However, the authors verified that PHBV and lignosulfonate thermal degradation processes are not independent. The deviations of predicted char residue values were higher for samples with low lignosulfonate proportions. Therefore, the behavior of char residue was not the same for all samples, since it fluctuated according to lignin content.

Thus, the different behavior observed for the char residues of 50:50 and 80:20 lignin/PHBV composites can be due to a better mixture between lignin and PHBV in these proportions, leading to more intense interactions in their degradation processes, in a manner similar to that mentioned by Lemes et al.41

Mousavioun et al.42 studied the thermal stability and miscibility of poly(hydroxybutyrate) and soda lignin blends. Although the authors do not discuss the values of char residue obtained in the TGA analysis of their PHB/lignin samples (10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, and 90 wt% of soda lignin), the curves showed that the char residue of all blends was higher than lignin pure. An increase of thermal stability was verified to all PHBV/lignin blends, however, the temperatures of 50% weight loss (T50) blends increased more than expected for proportion of soda lignin added in the case of 90:10 and 80:20 PHBV/lignin blend. The authors suggest that it occurs due to some degree of miscibility between these components in these proportions, while in blends with soda lignin concentrations higher than 20 wt% there is incompatibility between the components. These results indicate still that lignin degradation products react with PHB degradation products to form stable species.

Thus, in the present work, the higher char residue of 50:50 and 80:20 lignin/PHBV compared to pure lignin may be caused by a better mixture of components in these proportions, in which the lignin degradation products react with PHBV degradation products to form no volatile species.

sec.title: Mechanical tests
sec.p: The addition of a high lignin amount in the composites implies lower cost. For this reason, the mechanical tests were carried out with 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV, since this was the maximum lignin proportion with which it was possible to produce specimens for mechanical tests. Above this proportion, the injected specimens of composites became extremely fragile and showed many defects.

Thus, the 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composites, extruded PHBV and not extruded PHBV were used in tensile and flexural tests. The average values of maximum tensile stress, elongation at break, Young’s modulus or modulus of elasticity, and tensile stress at break verified in tensile test are shown in Table 2. Table 2.
Average results of the tensile stress vs. strain test for extruded and not extruded PHBV and the 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composites
Samples Maximum tensile stress (MPa) Elongation at break (%) Young’s modulus (MPa) Tensile stress at break (MPa)
PHBV (not extruded) 23.4 ± 0.6 5.5 ± 0.4 853.3 ± 42.3 23.1 ± 0.7
PHBV (extruded) 24.1 ± 0.7 5.1 ± 0.4 900.4 ± 47.3 24.0 ± 0.7
50:50 (w/w) Lignin/PHBV 7.6 ± 0.8 2.1 ± 0.2 753.7 ± 61.7 7.6 ± 0.7
*
Average values for eight probes assayed by each sample.

The results in Table 2 showed that the tensile properties of extruded and not extruded PHBV were similar; it indicates that the PHBV did not undergo degradations that caused loss of mechanical property during its processing. We can verify also a decrease of mechanical properties with lignin addition. The maximum tensile stress of 50:50 lignin/PHBV composite was about 70% lower than both PHBV samples. The decrease of elongation at break, Young’s modulus and tensile stress at break indicates that this composite is less resistant and less rigid than both PHBV samples.

The flexural test is usually used to characterize materials that exhibit fragile behavior, as PHBV and the 50:50 lignin/PHBV composite. Thus, the average values of the flexural modulus and the maximum flexural stress were obtained from flexural stress–strain curves of these materials (not shown) and reported in Table 3. Table 3.
Average results of the flexural stress vs. strain test for extruded and not extruded PHBV and the 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composites
Samples Maximum flexural stress (MPa) Flexural modulus (MPa)
PHBV (not extruded) 30.1 ± 1.8 1779.0 ± 101
PHBV (extruded) 35.0 ± 1.4 2107.0 ± 100
50:50 (w/w) Lignin/PHBV 15.2 ± 2.0 2344.0 ± 169
*
Average values for 8 probes assayed by each sample.

The extruded PHBV flexural mechanical properties were slightly higher than not extruded PHBV properties, according to the maximum flexural stress and flexural modulus values in the Table 3, which could be related to obtaining better specimens due to previous fusion and mixing of PHBV pellets. However, a decrease of flexural resistance was observed in the case of 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV, since its maximum flexural stress was lower (~50%) than both PHBV samples.

Therefore, although there is milder slight increase of 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composite flexural modulus compared to extruded PHBV flexural modulus, we can claim based on tensile and flexural mechanical tests that the lignin addition into PHBV matrix caused loss of mechanical properties in this case.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
sec.p:
The Figure 5 shows the surface morphology of 20:80, 40:60, 60:40, and 80:20 lignin/PHBV composites that were prepared in the Haake mixer. The SEM images reveal that the increment of lignin content results in irregular and brittle surfaces. Thus, the 20:80 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composite (Figure 5(a)) exhibits a bright and smooth surface, while the 80:20 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composite exhibits an opaque surface with poor cohesion (Figure 5(d)). Figure 5.
Scanning electron microscopy micrographs of lignin/PHBV composites: (a) 20:80, (b) 40:60, (c) 60:40, and (d) 80:20.

The cryogenic fracture of 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composite enabled the SEM analysis of its cross section surface, as shown by Figure 6(a) and (b). In these SEM images, no physical contact between filler and polymeric matrix was verified. This occurs because there is no interaction between lignin and PHBV. The voids at the filler/matrix interface make the composite porous. This affects the stress transference between filler and matrix leading to low mechanical properties. Figure 6.
Scanning electron microscopy micrographs for 50:50 lignin/PHBV composites obtained from cryogenically fractured cross-section surface. Magnification: (a) 1000× and (b) 500×.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The introduction of lignin in PHBV matrix did not alter the thermal behavior of PHBV related to Tg, Tm and PHBV’s crystallinity in the composites. However, the thermal decomposition profile of composites depends on the lignin/PHBV proportions. The composites residual masses are directly related to lignin content, thus, high lignin amounts cause the increase of composites residual mass. This increase was higher than the expected one for 50:50 and 80:20 (w/w) lignin/PHBV, probably because a better mixture of the lignin and PHBV in these proportions entailed in the production of no volatile species during the PHBV and lignin degradation process.

The study demonstrated that a lignin content above 60% (w/w) result in a fragile and brittle material. The maximum lignin content that permitted the making of mechanical test specimens was 50% lignin weight.

The 50:50 (w/w) lignin/PHBV composites showed a decrease of mechanical properties compared with pure PHBV, which was more pronounced for tensile properties than for flexural properties. This decrease was attributed to zero interaction between lignin and PHBV, which induces the absence of physical contact between filler and the polymeric matrix, and consequently, prevents the stress transfer in the filler/matrix interface.

However, the utilization of renewable components, and the decrease in cost of the final material make the production of lignin/PHBV composites promising in agriculture, in applications where the biodegradability is desirable and high mechanical properties are not necessary, as the production of biodegradable containers for seedlings, for example.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors acknowledge FAPESP, Pronex, and CNPq for financial supports and express our appreciation to M.M.M. De Azevedo during the first stages of our work.
